pull.title: No need to use OpenSSL malloc/free
pull.body: The set of objects used in the OpenSSL locking callback do not need to be allocated using the OpenSSL allocator.

events.body: Please be aware the we use the [trivial] label for changes that are essentially non-code changes. i.e fixing typos. This PR would not be considered trivial.

rename.from: [trivial] No need to use OpenSSL malloc/free
rename.to: No need to use OpenSSL malloc/free

events.body: Ack. will remove the trivial marker when I update the PR for the apparently broken test.
Bump, for one less OpenSSL eyesore

events.message: No need to use OpenSSL malloc/free

comments.body:
~~AFAIK it was slightly wrong to free the ppmutexOpenSSL via `OPENSSL_free`. IMO only objects alloced by `OPENSSL_malloc()` should use `OPENSSL_free()`. This change makes sense.~~
I was wrong: It is currently (master) alloced with `OPENSSL_malloc`.

It is allocated via OPENSSL_malloc
```
ppmutexOpenSSL = (CCriticalSection**)OPENSSL_malloc(CRYPTO_num_locks() * sizeof(CCriticalSection*));
```

> It is allocated via OPENSSL_malloc

Oh. Right.. it was. Nervermind then.
Probably cleaner to just use a `std::unique_ptr<CCriticalSection[]>`
and then here `ppmutexOpenSSL.reset(new CCriticalSection[CRYPTO_num_locks()]);` I think is correct.
You are correct.  I always like shaving lines off.
